Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned a lot about analyzing primary sources
I learned how to analyze ancient sources.
Evaluating ancient primary sources and their biases.
A lot about how to read primary sources, mostly.
This class gave great insight into the Hellenistic world.
I learned about the period of history between the Roman Empire and the Classic Greek period
I learned a lot about Hellenistic history from the rise of Philip II of Macedon to the decline of the Hellenistic world with the rise of Rome.
Knowledge on Hellenistic civilization

As the title suggests, I learned about Alexander the Great and the Hellenistic world. This was an incredible period in history that often gets overlooked. There are lots of cool stories and themes strikingly similar to our own times.
The history of Alex the Great and the time around his life

My knowledge of the historical context of Alexander the Great's conquests was greatly increased. I gained greater insight into the occurrences before Alexander the Great came into power, as well as the effects of his military campaign. My historical writing skills also were improved greatly.
I gained a deep introduction to the Hellenistic age through major primary sources and scholarship about the subject.
This class especially taught me the importance of document and source analysis when regarding history and how it has been presented.

Great insight into a rather un-talked-about period of history. Great overview lectures from Prof. Manning supplemented with interesting primary / secondary sources. Questions like: Who was Alexander the Great, and why did he do what he did? (The answer is we can't really know.) How did people live in the tumultuous years after his reign? What was the world that Rome conquered?
Very interesting look at a period in European history not often considered all that important.

I learned how to evaluate history by focusing on primary and secondary sources from the time period. I also learned an immense amount about the important time period between Alexander the Great and Julius Caesar.

I learned a great deal by taking this course. Previously, I knew almost nothing about Alexander the Great and even less about the subsequent Hellenistic world (except for what I had learned from Andrew Johnston's Roman Republic class). After taking this course, I feel like I have a very strong grasp of the history of Alexander the Great and a relatively strong grasp of the history of the subsequent Hellenistic period.
The lectures can be a little scattered but the study guides are incredibly helpful and the course is really interesting

This course needs better organization and focus. The lectures bounced around and had no trend and the readings were hard to follow and never seemed to relate back to the material we learned that week.

1. there is too much reading assigned, so no one does all of the reading each week
2. lectures during the 2nd half of the semester were too focused on sociology and other niche aspects of history, as opposed to the political "real" history that the course relied on earlier.
3. The first exam had a great format. Nice how hard work directly translates to success. 
4. The 2nd exam had an okay format, but the first question source analysis seemed superfluous.

I like how the lectures were to elaborate on the readings, and I liked how they were more narrative and theme-based, but they could ramble sometimes and I would lose sight of what the overall meaning of the lecture was.
This course was overall very strong.
We could have spent more time on Alexander the Great

The largest strength of this course is the subject matter. The readings and the time period that this class covers are incredibly interesting. It ties together the grandeur of classical Greece with the glory of the Roman Empire.

That said, this class was not very well organized. The TAs (who were excellent in my experience) seems to need to pester Professor Manning for any sort of clarity on the upcoming assignments (papers!). The lecture slides and notes were not posted in an organized manner, and often not posted at all. If you don't want to post the lecture slides, that's fine. But please don't tell us you're going to and then not!

Please provide additional clarity about the papers earlier in the semester (lengths of assignments not released in the syllabus!). For writing credit, grade makeup should be 30% midterm, 30% section/papers, 40% final. For three papers plus section participation, 25% is too little!

I understand that Professor Manning is an excellent historian and extremely intelligent man, but his class would've benefitted from this additional level of organization. The lectures themselves were a bit jumpy and often posed more questions than they answered.

Interesting content, but many times the format of the class made it so that it was more important to do the readings than go to the lectures as we were only tested on those. 
Also, while it is interesting to study history by topics, I did feel lost on the timeline of events most of the time and it would be nice if rather than just saying the years, there was a bit more contextualizing.
Very interesting material, taught very well.
Please do the course chronologically - it was SO confusing to have it taught by geographical sections and themes.
The lectures were interesting and engaging. The discussion periods allowed students to clear up any confusion they may have had and to gain greater insight into specific occurrences.

The primary source readings for the class are a lot of fun, but sometimes the secondary source readings were overwhelming. Overall, I think the balance was fine by the end of the semester. Lectures were mostly fascinating, but sometimes a bit unorganized and too reflective of the powerpoints. Two TA's (Andy and Liam) gave excellent guest lectures.

This course was able to combine the leading documents on the Hellenistic age to try and create a holistic view of the age. Yet, it challenged us to see if the view truly was holistic or whether there were some things that needed further investigating or were tougher to truly decipher than previously thought.

The biggest weakness of the course was the structure and nature of the assessment. I felt that the subject matter of the class tailored more to a written paper than an exam, and I think it would have been better to have assigned a longer paper in lieu of a final exam. The structure of the final exam, which basically was two essays, reflected that and it would've been more conducive to the students I think to have just had us write a paper drawing from a wide variety of sources and the things we learned in class than to give us a couple of essay questions in advance and have us prepare essays to write in a three-hour period. 
Also for a class about Alexander the Great and the Hellenistic World, it might have been nice to have focused at least for another week on Alexander, it felt like we skipped over him fairly quickly and while admittedly the primary source base isn't great I think we definitely could have managed to do another week on him. Or you could just take him out of the course title.
For the WR credit: A lot of paper writing but worth less than 25% of the grade. Could be skewed a little more in favor of the papers. The reading is all excellent and super interesting.

I think this class is excellent! I learned much more and was much more interested than I thought I would be. Professor Manning is an excellent lecturer. I think one of the strengths of this class is its focus on studying ancient sources over modern surveys of the period; I think this is very important because for many students like me, this may be their first or only class in ancient history. I think one of the weaknesses of this class is its lack of focus on Alexander himself; while of course in a 300-year time period only so much time can be dedicated to one person, Alexander the Great is a fascinating figure (and half of the title of the course) as well as an important one, and for that reason I believe that this class could benefit from focusing on this figure more than it did.

The biggest strength of this course was Professor Manning, who I will discuss further later. The other main strength of the course was its material - Alexander the Great and the Hellenistic period is a fascinating period of ancient history that is regrettably understudied compared to Classical Greece and Rome. It was in particular interesting noting how Hellenistic history constantly interacted - from effectively the very start - with Roman Republican history. Regrettably, however, the course did have one main weakness: the amount of reading. It was simply unnecessary how much Errington in particular was often assigned, and often how many Austin sources were assigned; many of the articles were redundant or excessively long as well. It was also then frustrating because we didn't have time in section to go over the vast majority of the reading that had been assigned.

Probably not, while it was interesting it was really difficult to study for things because I was unsure what the purpose of the class was. The themes were very hard to identify because I'm not sure that there were many, if any, that were emphasized.

I took this class for the 300+ level credit and for the pre-industrial credit, so I took the non-writing section. Overall, this class is a mixed bag. I learned A LOT about Hellenistic History, and the subject matter is pretty interesting in of itself. Unfortunately, a lot of this learning was done on my own, in the days before the exam. The lectures start off strong, but quickly wander onto niche subjects later in the semester. Consequently, lecture attendance is rather poor. The level of reading you need to do is highly dependent on your TF, but no one does all of the reading each week. On the bright side, the exams are very straightforward, as Manning basically releases all the possible questions ahead of time and then picks a few you have to answer. If you put in the work to study, you WILL be rewarded with a fairly good grade, which is more than I can say about some of the other lectures I've taken at Yale. Overall, I would recommend this class for those looking for: a low workload class, a 300+ level/preindustrial for the major, predictable grades, a class that you don't have to attend lecture, or for learning about an underappreciated historical period. I would NOT recommend this class for those who want riveting lectures, or dislike primary source analyses.

This is a great course to take as a PI for the history major. Manning's lectures and especially engaging, and the workload is not too tough at all. It offers a great introduction to the Ancient world and analyzing some really interesting primary sources. Very glad I took this course.

I really enjoyed this class. As a history major, it was interesting material about an important period of time that I didn't know much about. There were a lot of classic majors who liked to flex about how much they knew about the period though.
I absolutely would, as it enhanced my knowledge of the ancient world.
Yes, if they were interested in Ancient History

I would recommend this to any student interested in taking a class in ancient history. As many other reviews identify, Alexander the Great actually dies in about the third week of the semester. The history that follows, however, is incredibly interesting. I'm an S&DS/Econ major, and I've taken two other history dept classes. I took this for a WR, and I enjoyed the content more than any other history class that I've taken.

That said, the workload was much more than advertised. You actually need to do the reading (for real!) if you take the writing section (at least the stuff in the Austin anthology, which is very manageable) in order to write the papers. The papers themselves were longer than expected: first was about 7-9 pages, the second about 10-12 pages, and the third was to add 3-4 pages to your second paper.
yup!
Yes, it was interesting! There are a lot of readings but it's a way of learning how history is studied in a more formal level.
I would recommend since it's a cool subject. Where else would you learn about ancient war elephants and sarissas?

I'm not sure I would recommend this course to another student. The subject matter is interesting, and I learned a lot more about the period, but I think the course was not terribly well organized. The reading amounts varied a lot week to week, whereas the lectures consistently had low amounts of information and felt disorganized to the point of having trouble taking notes sometimes. I think the key themes of the course came through clearly, though. I didn't take the writing section, so I can't speak to that element.
Yes - very interesting and if you do the bulk of the readings I assure you the course will be way more interesting
Yes, but actually do the readings. I essentially had to learn the entire course three days before the final and turns out it's actually really interesting.

I would recommend this course to any student that is interested in the life of Alexander the Great and ancient history. Although I do not wish to major in history, I appreciated the insight that this course had to offer and I enjoyed taking the class very much.

If you are at all interested in what happend after Alexander the Great dies and before the Roman Empire began Id recommend it. Id also recommend it to history majors looking for a lighter workload or for people looking to balance their majors with a good class with a manageable workload.

I would definitely recommend the course to anyone interested in understanding the complicated historical period between classical Athens and Rome -- it's absolutely a brilliant time that fills in a significant gap that is looked over in most history courses (and DS).

Manning is a disorganized teacher and lecturer, and teaches you very little directly during class. The class focuses on analyzing sources and gives you very little direct knowledge of the period.  This is partly because the source material is sparse from this period.  The exams do not test knowledge of the period but knowledge of obscure source material.   If you want to go to grad school for ancient history then take, if you want to learn something, then beware.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student as it is informative and challenges previous held notions.
Yea probably. I did it because I find the period to be very interesting, so I came in with pretty high expectations and I don't think the class really met them.
Absolutely. Anyone interested in getting into ancient history should take this course. You see the big (troop movements, politics etc) and small (how people lived).
I think I'd recommend this course. The material was interesting enough. The exams were fair and as someone in the WR section, the essays weren't terrible. It's worth a look.
Yes, take it! Prof. Manning is a great lecturer, and you won't really learn about this stuff in such an in-depth manner in another context.

I would recommend this class to another student for many reasons. Firstly, if a student wishes to gain a better understanding of how to study ancient history as compared to more contemporary history, this class is an excellent introduction. Secondly, this class is an excellent example of history done right in general; if you are going to take only a few history courses at Yale, this should be one of them.

I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in history, especially Western history. The Hellenistic period is a key period for understanding the comprehensive arc of Ancient (Western) history - without understanding Alexander and the Hellenistic period, it is hard to have a thorough grasp of the Ancient Western world.
